title_sort: walter whitman reynolds to walt whitman, 9 february 1870
title: Walter Whitman Reynolds to Walt Whitman, 9 February 1870
text: New YorkFeb 9. /70Dear friend WalterI now take my pen in hand to let you know how I am getting along. I am doing well at present & I hope you are the Same. we have had a very heavy Snow-Storm here on tuesday it did not aount to much as it was very Damp it was very bad walking here the last two Days I am very Sorry for to Keep you waiting So long for your Answer I received your letter of the Eight & was very glad to hear from you. we have been Stopingstopping at my Sisters for the last few weeks & we have been very unsettled & that is the reason I did not write before. I am going to buy a fraim[frame] for your Picture I have it up in my room I would like to see you very much it has been a long while since I wh think Visit to Washington when you were here getting along nicely now has steady work he works at the pipe yard at the foot of twenty-fourth St. East river. Boss Mr Hawkins is going to leave the firm the first of march & my friend Oliver Allen & I thought we would like to make Mr Hawkins a present of a gold Lead Pencil to remember us by. I think that would be as useful an Articalarticle as we could give we saw a very nice gold Pencil at fairchilds for four Dollars that would be two Dollars a peicepiece If you would be so kind as to send me two Dollars in your next letter you need not send me any more Spending money for months to ther I must bid you good by[goodbye] for the present from your loving friend.Walter Whitman Reynolds Walter Whitman Reynolds to Walt Whitman, 9 February 1870
